facts.text: On 16th July 1952, Mangilal received threatening letter Exhibit P-5 demanding Rs. 5000 by 6:30 pm on 17th July at crossing near 27th milestone on Ajmer-Bijainagar road, threatening death if not complied or police informed.
Letter delivered to Mangilal's son Laduram, who took it with envelope to uncle Ramjas at Ajmer; they showed it to Superintendent of Police and sought protection, but no action taken.

On 17th July 1952 at about 9:30 pm, Mangilal sitting at shop with Gajanand writing accounts; two persons arrived - one in khaki suit, one in blue suit; blue demanded reply to letter, khaki took Mangilal's gun from wall; Mangilal said son took letter to Ajmer; blue fired Mauser pistol, killing Mangilal; assailants ran, threw pistol and khaki clothes nearby.
FIR lodged by Nand Lal (PW1) at 9:45 pm on 17th July 1952, describing two men (khaki with hat, blue with cap); blue took gun, khaki spoke, blue shot Mangilal.
Prosecution charged four: Hem Raj, Hukum Singh, Milap Singh, Abdul Hakim for conspiracy to extort via threats; Exhibit P-5 sent in pursuance.
Hem Raj and Hukum Singh arrested evening of 26th July 1952 at Bijainagar, sent to jail 28th July 1952.
Hem Raj confessed before Magistrate on 30th July 1952 in jail.
Confession retracted on 5th September 1952 before committing Magistrate via counsel application.
Sessions Judge (18th March 1953, Sessions Trial No.1/1953): acquitted Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim; convicted Hem Raj and Hukum Singh.
Judicial Commissioner Ajmer (25th April 1953): dismissed Hem Raj's appeal (Criminal Appeal 13/1953), allowed Hukum Singh's appeal (14/15/1953), acquitted Hukum Singh.
Recoveries from Hem Raj's house on 18th July 1952: hat, mask, bush shirt, pistol.
Recoveries on 25th July 1952 from Hem Raj's house.
Hem Raj delivered: black socks, slate coloured muffler, blue shorts, torch.
Recoveries from roof of Bansilal's shop on 27th July 1952: revolver, cartridges.
Recovery of gun case and gun.
Gajanand (PW34, eyewitness): man in blue had pistol, fired fatal shot.
Key Exhibit P-12 found in Hukum Singh's trouser pocket; latch removed from his shop.
Hem Raj runs cycle shop in Bijainagar.
Hukum Singh declined to confess when Magistrate approached, wanted to consult lawyer.
SC special leave: Hem Raj on 30th June 1953, State on 27th October 1953.

legal_issues.text: Whether Hem Raj's confession was voluntary, free from inducement, threat or compulsion, and thus admissible.
Whether Hem Raj's confession was corroborated in material particulars.
Whether evidence sufficient to convict Hukum Singh.
Scope of Supreme Court interference under Article 136: only exceptional circumstances of grave injustice.

petitioner_arguments.text: Confession inadmissible: not proved voluntary; preceded by inducement/threats by police (eager for approver due to negligence); illegal custody before jail; SP visit in jail; Magistrate did not disclose identity, recorded in jail.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles from Taylor's Evidence (11th Edn., p.588 par.872); Queen v. Thompson (1893 2 QB 12)

petitioner_arguments.text: No independent corroboration of material facts; recoveries pre-confession, known to police; no new discovery; merely recital of police knowledge.
Inference that Hem Raj posted Exhibit P-5 unreasonable merely from presence in Beawar.

respondent_arguments.text: Confession voluntary: made in jail after 36+ hours, detailed (21 pages, facts unknown to police); Magistrate complied with safeguards; no evidence of inducement; retracted only after legal advice.
Corroboration: eyewitness Gajanand (blue suit fired); recoveries of clothes, arms, ammo post-arrest; new facts in confession (30 bore cartridges, Mauser pistol, letter posting).
Against Hukum Singh: he wrote P-5; key P-12 in pocket; latch broken; seen with Hem Raj.

court_reasoning.text: No interference under Art.136 unless grave injustice; appeals do not raise such points; limited to points urged at leave stage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Admission by special leave does not open whole case.

court_reasoning.text: Confession voluntary: concurrent findings below; made in jail 2 days after, 36+ hrs reflection; detailed, precise facts unknown/tutored impossibly; Magistrate's safeguards complied; retraction delayed, vague; Hem Raj not rustic.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Police could not dream/tutor such details; Hukum Singh refused similarly.

court_reasoning.text: Irregularities (recorded in jail, pre-jail custody) do not vitiate; no material for inducement/threats; bald assertions insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle from Queen v. Thompson followed; suspicion dispelled by time elapsed.

court_reasoning.text: Corroboration sufficient: Gajanand (blue fired); recoveries (clothes, pistol, revolver, cartridges, gun); independent; pre-known facts usable for corroboration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mata Din concerns value, not nature of corroborative evidence; confessions can use prior evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Hem Raj posted P-5 inference reasonable in circumstances.
Hem Raj's confession not substantive against Hukum Singh; other evidence (handwriting, key, latch, association) insufficient; benefit of doubt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial Commissioner right; no material for interference with acquittal.

holdings.text: Confession voluntary and admissible; sufficiently corroborated in material particulars.
Evidence with confession proves charges under Sections 302/34 and 386 IPC against Hem Raj.
Insufficient evidence to convict Hukum Singh; entitled to acquittal.

precedents_cited.relevance: Confession must be affirmatively proved free/voluntary, no preceding inducement by authority.
Concerns value of confession adding to police knowledge; does not bar using pre-known facts for corroboration.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Limits SC interference to exceptional grave injustice cases.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Examination of accused; confession recording safeguards.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Murder with common intention; extortion by putting in fear of death.

outcome.summary: Hem Raj's appeal dismissed, conviction under Sections 302/34 and 386 IPC upheld. State's appeal against Hukum Singh's acquittal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Unless it is shown that exceptional and special circumstances exist that substantial and grave injustice has been done... this Court does not exercise its overriding powers under article 136."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limited scope of SC review in special leave appeals.

key_quotes.text: "The police could not even dream of these details or make an effort to tutor such a detailed confession to the prisoner."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Underscores why confession deemed voluntary and genuine.

key_quotes.text: "A confession can be corroborated by evidence discovered by the police after a confession has been made and any material that is already in their possession, cannot be put in evidence in support of it." (rejecting contention)
key_quotes.speaker: court
